title: 107_hr2097
content: The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" is the short title of this legislation. The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" highlights the importance of early brain development and quality early care and education for children. Research shows that early learning and nurturing care significantly impact a child's growth and long-term success in school and life. Approximately 13,000,000 children, including 6,000,000 infants and toddlers, receive child care daily, but only 1 in 7 meet quality standards. The importance of quality early care and education for children is highlighted in the "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001." Research shows that early learning significantly impacts long-term school success and economic self-sufficiency. Approximately 13,000,000 children, including 6,000,000 infants and toddlers, receive child care daily, but only 1 in 7 centers meet quality standards. Full-day child care can cost $4,000 to $10,000 per year. Child care centers provide care that promotes healthy development, but 1 in 8 centers pose risks to children's safety. Full-day child care costs $4,000 to $10,000 annually, with limited Federal assistance available. Families with a monthly income under $1,200 may spend 25% of their income on child care. Payment rates determine reimbursement for child care services. Even with Federal subsidies, many families struggle to afford child care, with costs consuming 25% of their income for those earning under $1,200 monthly. Low reimbursement rates impact the quality of care children receive and hinder access to quality child care for all families. The State's low reimbursement rates for child care providers receiving subsidies hinder access to quality care for all families, leading to cut corners that lower the quality of care for children. Low reimbursement rates for child care providers force cuts in staff, training, and educational activities, leading to lower quality care for children. This can result in delayed skills development and increased aggression. Higher payment rates enable providers to offer better care by attracting qualified staff, providing training, and maintaining a safe environment. Increased payment rates improve child care quality by allowing providers to attract and retain qualified staff, offer salary increases and professional training, maintain a safe environment, and purchase necessary supplies. The purpose of this Act is to enhance the quality and accessibility of child care through increased payment rates. Incentive grants are provided to improve the quality of child care. Funding for improving the quality of child care is authorized with $500,000,000 appropriated for fiscal year 2002. Funds of $500,000,000 are authorized for grants to enhance child care quality. The text chunk discusses the appropriation of $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years for grants under section 658H of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act. Amendments are made to the use of block grant funds under section 658E(c)(3) and the establishment of a program under section 658G(a). Amendments are made to the use of block grant funds under section 658E(c)(3) and the establishment of a program under section 658G(a) of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. "Grants are provided to enhance child care quality under section 658H." The Secretary will use appropriated funds to make grants to eligible States for child care services based on market rates surveys conducted within the past 2 years. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must have conducted a market rates survey for child care services within the past 2 years and submit an application as specified. To receive a grant under this section, a State must have conducted a market rates survey for child care services within the past 2 years and submit an application to the Secretary with required information. To apply for a grant under this section, a State must submit an application to the Secretary with required information, including details of the market rates survey conducted and the State's plan. Each grant application must include details of the State market rates survey, a plan to increase payment rates, and how rates will be adjusted based on survey results. The State's plan to increase payment rates must be described, along with how rates will be adjusted based on market survey results. The Secretary will only make annual payments to eligible States if progress is made in activities assisted under the grant application. The Secretary will only make annual payments to eligible States if progress is made in maintaining increased payment rates through activities assisted under the grant application. States must conduct an update of the market survey described in the paragraph at least once every 2 years to be eligible for funding. Matching funds are also required for eligibility. To be eligible for annual payments, States must maintain increased payment rates and update the market survey every 2 years. States also need to provide matching funds of at least 25% of the costs for activities under the grant application. The State must provide at least 25% of the costs for activities under the grant application in cash, without including amounts from the Federal Government. State contributions must be in cash and cannot include amounts from the Federal Government. Allotments to eligible States are determined in the same manner as under another section. Funds received must be used to increase the payment rate for services. An eligible State receiving a grant must use the funds to increase the payment rate for child care assistance up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. The eligible State receiving a grant can significantly increase the payment rate for child care assistance up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Additionally, if the State achieves this payment rate, they can use the funds for activities that enhance the quality of child care services. The State can use grant funds to enhance child care services if it achieves the 100th percentile payment rate. Amounts received should supplement, not supplant, other funds. The State must use grant funds to improve child care services by reaching the 100th percentile payment rate. Funds should supplement, not replace, other sources of funding. States must submit evaluations to the Secretary on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality and accessibility. The State must submit evaluations to the Secretary on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality and accessibility. The Secretary will then submit biennial reports to Congress based on this information. The Secretary will submit biennial reports to Congress on the information provided by States regarding efforts to increase payment rates for subsidized child care. The reports will include data from applications as a baseline for tracking progress. The Secretary will submit biennial reports to Congress on States' progress in maintaining increased payment rates for subsidized child care. Amendments are made to sections regarding payments and allotment in the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to specify funding sources and allotment procedures. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to specify funding sources and allotment procedures, including adjustments to section 658B(a) and subsection (b)(1) regarding allotments.
